column7: ここに至るまでの道のりは長かった。
column8: The journey to this point was long.
column9: Koko ni itaru made no michinori wa nagakatta.
column10: Commonly used for reaching a destination or result.

column7: 現在の政治情勢は非常に不安定だ。
column8: The current political situation is very unstable.
column9: Genzaiteki seiji jōsei wa hijō ni fuan tei da.
column10: Used in contexts involving situations or conditions.

column7: 気象庁は台風の進行状況を観測している。
column8: The meteorological agency is observing the typhoon.
column9: Kishōchō wa taifū no shinkō jōkyō o kansoku shiteiru.
column10: Used for scientific or weather-related observations.

column7: 洪水のため、河川の水位が急激に上昇した。
column8: Due to the flood, the river's water level rapidly increased.
column9: Kōzui no tame, kasen no sui-i ga kyūgeki ni jōshō shita.
column10: Used in environmental or flood-related contexts.

column5: guerrilla (also refers to unexpectedly strong rain)
column7: ゲリラ豪雨で街が冠水した。
column8: The city was flooded by a guerrilla downpour.
column9: Gerira gōu de machi ga kansui shita.
column10: Refers to sudden, intense rainfall.

column7: 豪雨が続いているため、外に出るのが危険だ。
column8: It is dangerous to go outside because of the heavy rain.
column9: Gōu ga tsuzuiteiru tame, soto ni deru no ga kiken da.
column10: Describes very heavy or intense rainfall.

column7: 猛暑が続いているため、エアコンの使用が増えている。
column8: Air conditioner use has increased due to the heat wave.
column9: Mōsho ga tsuzuiteiru tame, eakon no shiyō ga fueteiru.
column10: Refers to extreme heat, often in summer.

column7: 今年の残暑は厳しい。
column8: This year’s late summer heat is harsh.
column9: Kotoshi no zansho wa kibishii.
column10: Refers to heat lingering after summer.

column7: 多くの動物が絶滅の危機に瀕している。
column8: Many animals are facing the risk of extinction.
column9: Ōku no dōbutsu ga zetsumetsu no kiki ni hin shiteiru.
column10: Used in environmental and conservation contexts.

column7: マラリアは蚊が媒介する病気です。
column8: Malaria is a disease transmitted by mosquitoes.
column9: Mararia wa ka ga baikai suru byōki desu.
column10: A tropical disease caused by mosquitoes.

column7: デング熱は熱帯地方で多く発生しています。
column8: Dengue fever occurs frequently in tropical areas.
column9: Dengu netsu wa nettai chiho de ōku hassei shiteimasu.
column10: A mosquito-borne disease common in tropical areas.

column7: この病気は空気感染します。
column8: This disease is airborne.
column9: Kono byōki wa kūki kansen shimasu.
column10: Used for medical or health-related contexts.

column5: unavoidable/owing to circumstance beyond one's control
column7: 余儀なく外出を控えることになった。
column8: I had to refrain from going out due to unavoidable circumstances.
column9: Yoginaku gaishutsu o hikaeru koto ni natta.
column10: Often used to describe situations that are forced or inevitable.

column7: その問題について識者の意見を聞くことが重要だ。
column8: It is important to listen to the expert’s opinion on this matter.
column9: Sono mondai ni tsuite shikisha no iken o kiku koto ga jūyō da.
column10: Refers to someone with deep knowledge or expertise.

column7: 彼は大きな目標を遂げた。
column8: He achieved his big goal.
column9: Kare wa ōkina mokuhyō o togeta.
column10: Often used for achieving personal goals or major achievements.

column7: 問題の根本原因を探る必要がある。
column8: We need to find the root cause of the problem.
column9: Mondai no konpon gen'in o saguru hitsuyō ga aru.
column10: Refers to the fundamental basis or cause of something.

column7: 会社のリストラが進んでいる。
column8: Layoffs are progressing in the company.
column9: Kaisha no risutora ga susundeiru.
column10: Commonly used in corporate downsizing or job cuts.

column7: 今年の予算は赤字になってしまった。
column8: This year’s budget ended up in deficit.
column9: Kotoshi no yoshan wa akaji ni natte shimatta.
column10: Refers to a financial loss or deficit.

column7: 会社は黒字で終わった。
column8: The company ended with a surplus.
column9: Kaisha wa kuroji de owatta.
column10: Refers to a financial gain or surplus.

column7: 彼の意見を尊重するべきだ。
column8: We should respect his opinion.
column9: Kare no iken o sonchō suru beki da.
column10: Refers to respecting or valuing someone's opinions or rights.

column7: 彼は人々の意見を重んずる。
column8: He values the opinions of others.
column9: Kare wa hitobito no iken o omonzuru.
column10: Similar to "respect," but often used in more formal contexts.

column7: 部屋の天井に穴が開いている。
column8: There is a hole in the ceiling of the room.
column9: Heya no tenjō ni ana ga aiteiru.
column10: Refers to the upper interior surface of a room.

column7: 新しいビルの内装はとてもモダンだ。
column8: The interior decoration of the new building is very modern.
column9: Atarashī biru no naisō wa totemo modan da.
column10: Refers to the decoration or design of the inside of a building.

column7: 彼は賄賂を受け取ったとして逮捕された。
column8: He was arrested for accepting a bribe.
column9: Kare wa wairo o uketotta to shite taiho sareta.
column10: Refers to illegal payments made to influence decisions.

column7: 彼は会社を辞職した。
column8: He resigned from the company.
column9: Kare wa kaisha o jishoku shita.
column10: Refers to voluntarily leaving a job or position.

column5: destruction/to destroy/to cancel (a contract)/to break (a promise)
column7: 彼は契約を破棄した。
column8: He canceled the contract.
column9: Kare wa keiyaku o haki shita.
column10: Often used for breaking promises or legal agreements.

column7: 会議中に沈黙が訪れた。
column8: Silence fell during the meeting.
column9: Kaigi-chū ni chinmoku ga otozureta.
column10: Refers to the act of becoming silent, often implying tension.

column7: 新しい企業が市場に参入した。
column8: A new company entered the market.
column9: Atarashī kigyō ga shijō ni sannyū shita.
column10: Commonly used in business and market contexts.

column7: 彼は窃盗の罪で逮捕された。
column8: He was arrested for theft.
column9: Kare wa settō no tsumi de taiho sareta.
column10: Used in legal contexts for crimes involving theft.

column7: 彼は壊れた商品を弁償した。
column8: He compensated for the damaged goods.
column9: Kare wa kowareta shōhin o benshō shita.
column10: Often used when compensating for damages or losses.

column5: I/myself (an old way of speaking with a nuance of arrogance)
column7: 吾輩は猫である。
column8: I am a cat. (from Natsume Sōseki’s famous novel)
column9: Wagahai wa neko de aru.
column10: A very old-fashioned and literary way to refer to oneself.

column7: この部屋はじめじめしている。
column8: This room is damp and gloomy.
column9: Kono heya wa jimajima shiteiru.
column10: Refers to an unpleasant, damp atmosphere or feeling.

column7: 昔の書生は非常に勤勉だった。
column8: Old-fashioned students were very diligent.
column9: Mukashi no shosei wa hijō ni kinben datta.
column10: A historic term for students, often used in literature.

column7: 彼の技術は一段と向上した。
column8: His skills have improved even further.
column9: Kare no gijutsu wa ichidanto kōjō shita.
column10: Used to emphasize an increase or improvement.

column7: いきなり彼は部屋に入ってきた。
column8: He suddenly entered the room.
column9: Ikinari kare wa heya ni haittekita.
column10: Refers to something unexpected or sudden happening.

column7: あの人の言っていることは怪しい。
column8: What that person is saying is suspicious.
column9: Ano hito no itte iru koto wa ayashii.
column10: Often implies something suspicious or doubtful.

column7: 危うく事故に遭いそうになった。
column8: I almost had an accident.
column9: Ayauku jiko ni aiso ni natta.
column10: Describes life-threatening or serious danger.

column7: 獰悪な態度で彼は対話を拒んだ。
column8: He refused to talk with a cruel attitude.
column9: Dōaku na taido de kare wa taiwa o kobanda.
column10: Describes a violent or extremely cruel nature.

column7: その種族は絶滅の危機に瀕している。
column8: That species is facing extinction.
column9: Sono shuzoku wa zetsumetsu no kiki ni hin shiteiru.
column10: Used in the context of biological species or ethnic groups.

column7: 彼女は掌に小さな傷を負っていた。
column8: She had a small cut on her palm.
column9: Kanojo wa tenohira ni chīsana kizu o otteita.
column10: Refers to the palm of the hand.

column7: 別段難しくはない。
column8: It’s not particularly difficult.
column9: Betsudan muzukashiku wa nai.
column10: Used to indicate something is not particularly special or important.

column7: 母は薬缶でお湯を沸かしている。
column8: My mother is boiling water in the kettle.
column9: Haha wa yakan de oyu o wakashiteiru.
column10: A kettle, typically for boiling water.

column7: クリスマスツリーは装飾が豊富だ。
column8: The Christmas tree is richly decorated.
column9: Kurisumasu tsurī wa sōshoku ga hōfu da.
column10: Refers to the decoration or adornment of something.

column7: 彼とは偶然に出会った。
column8: I came across him by chance.
column9: Kare to wa gūzen ni dekwatta.
column10: Used for meeting someone unexpectedly.

column7: 木の幹に突起ができている。
column8: A protrusion has formed on the tree trunk.
column9: Ki no miki ni tokkī ga dekite iru.
column10: Refers to something that sticks out or bulges.

column7: 火事の煙が遠くから見える。
column8: The smoke from the fire is visible from afar.
column9: Kaji no kemuri ga tōku kara mieru.
column10: Refers to the visible smoke, usually from a fire.

column7: 彼は何かを呟いていた。
column8: He was muttering something.
column9: Kare wa nanika o tsubuyaku shiteita.
column10: Often used for speaking quietly or complaining.

column7: 体裁を整えるために、服を着替えた。
column8: I changed clothes to improve my appearance.
column9: Teisai o totonoeru tame ni, fuku o kigaeta.
column10: Refers to the outward appearance or manners.

column7: 適宜対応してください。
column8: Please respond appropriately.
column9: Tekigi taio shite kudasai.
column10: Used to indicate an appropriate action in context.

column5: to blame/to reprimand/to feel guilty/to interrogate
column7: 彼はその件について咎められた。
column8: He was reprimanded for that matter.
column9: Kare wa sono ken ni tsuite togarereta.
column10: Refers to accusing, blaming, or questioning someone.

column7: 彼らは和やかな雰囲気の中で話していた。
column8: They were talking in a harmonious atmosphere.
column9: Karera wa nagoyaka na fun'iki no naka de hanashiteita.
column10: Describes a peaceful or friendly atmosphere.

column7: 彼は巧みにその計画を立てた。
column8: He cleverly made the plan.
column9: Kare wa takumi ni sono keikaku o tateta.
column10: Refers to skillfully planning or scheming.

column7: 彼は巧みな手腕で問題を解決した。
column8: He solved the problem with skillful hands.
column9: Kare wa takumi na shuwan de mondai o kaiketsu shita.
column10: Describes a high level of skill or cleverness.

column7: この布は粗い感じがする。
column8: This cloth feels coarse.
column9: Kono nuno wa arai kanji ga suru.
column10: Describes something rough or unrefined in texture.

column7: 渋い味の茶を飲んでいる。
column8: I’m drinking a bitter tea.
column9: Shibui aji no cha o nondeiru.
column10: Describes a refined or bitter taste, or a serious demeanor.

column7: 彼の努力は著しい成果を生んだ。
column8: His efforts produced remarkable results.
column9: Kare no doryoku wa ichijirushī seika o unda.
column10: Refers to something notable or outstanding.

column7: とりわけ、あの映画は素晴らしかった。
column8: That movie was especially wonderful.
column9: Toriwake, ano eiga wa subarashikatta.
column10: Used to emphasize something particularly noteworthy.

column7: 雨で計画が台無しになった。
column8: The plan was ruined by the rain.
column9: Ame de keikaku ga dainashi ni natta.
column10: Refers to something being spoiled or ruined.

column7: 月並みな回答をすることは避けたほうがいい。
column8: It's better to avoid giving ordinary answers.
column9: Tsukinami na kaitō o suru koto wa sakeeta hō ga ii.
column10: Refers to something predictable or commonplace.

column7: 彼の話には辻褄が合わない。
column8: His story doesn’t make sense.
column9: Kare no hanashi ni wa tsujitsuma ga awanai.
column10: Refers to the logical consistency or coherence of a situation.

column7: どうにかしてその問題を解決しなければならない。
column8: We have to solve this problem somehow.
column9: Dōnika shite sono mondai o kaiketsu shinakereba naranai.
column10: Used when dealing with a challenging situation.

column7: 資源が乏しい国々が多い。
column8: Many countries have scarce resources.
column9: Shigen ga toboshii kuniguni ga ōi.
column10: Refers to a lack or shortage of something.

column7: 彼は名高い作家だ。
column8: He is a famous writer.
column9: Kare wa nadakai sakka da.
column10: Describes someone or something well-known or renowned.

column7: この計画は今すぐには成り立たない。
column8: This plan can’t materialize right away.
column9: Kono keikaku wa ima sugu ni wa naritatsanai.
column10: Refers to something that comes together or is viable.

column7: 彼のピアノの音色は美しい。
column8: The tone of his piano is beautiful.
column9: Kare no piano no neiro wa utsukushii.
column10: Refers to the quality or tone of sound, especially musical.

column7: 店で 20%の値引きが行われている。
column8: A 20% discount is being offered at the store.
column9: Mise de 20% no nebiki ga okonawarete iru.
column10: Used in the context of reducing prices.

column5: to pretend not to know/to play the fool
column7: 彼はその質問に対してとぼけて答えた。
column8: He played innocent and answered that question.
column9: Kare wa sono shitsumon ni taishite tobokete kotaeta.
column10: Refers to feigning ignorance or pretending.

column7: この問題の重要性を把握するのは難しい。
column8: It’s difficult to grasp the importance of this issue.
column9: Kono mondai no jūyō-sei o haaku suru no wa muzukashii.
column10: Refers to understanding or comprehending something clearly.

column5: to peel/to tear off/to strip/to deprive
column7: 果物の皮を剥ぐのは楽しい。
column8: It’s fun to peel fruit.
column9: Kudamono no kawa o hagu no wa tanoshii.
column10: Refers to removing an outer layer or covering.

column7: 密かに計画を進めている。
column8: I am secretly advancing the plan.
column9: Hisoka ni keikaku o susumete iru.
column10: Refers to something done in secret or privacy.

column7: しばらく一息ついてから作業を再開した。
column8: After a short break, I resumed the work.
column9: Shibaraku hitoiki tsuite kara sagyō o saikai shita.
column10: Can mean taking a short rest or a little pause.

column7: 彼の人柄はとても温かい。
column8: His personality is very warm.
column9: Kare no hitogara wa totemo atatakai.
column10: Refers to someone’s character or personal traits.

column7: 今年の売り上げは不振だ。
column8: Sales this year are sluggish.
column9: Kotoshi no uriage wa fushin da.
column10: Refers to a situation that is stagnant or unsuccessful.

column7: 事件はすぐにメディアに報じられた。
column8: The incident was reported to the media immediately.
column9: Jiken wa sugu ni media ni hōjirareta.
column10: Refers to providing information or news.
